chunk_0-0: Given the deponent just confirmed he is a novice, I will immediately interject to withdraw our stipulation waiving his right to read and sign the transcript, stating on the record that a first-time witness must be afforded the opportunity to review his testimony for accuracy.
chunk_0-1: I would interject and instruct my client on the record: "Ma'am/Sir, I'm sorry to interrupt, but the court reporter can't take down a nod. For the entire deposition, you must answer out loud so she can get a clear record. Please answer the question verbally."
chunk_0-2: Interject to state for the record: "Just so we're clear, my client can request a break at any time, including after a question is asked and before it is answered, to confer with counsel. Please proceed."
chunk_0-3: Focus on ensuring the client anchors all future answers about his discussions with Mr. Marshall to the e-mails he reviewed, explicitly stating that those documents contain the accurate record, thereby preventing him from being impeached on the specifics of conversations he may not perfectly recall.
chunk_0-4: Focus the next line of questioning on establishing that the deponent saw no need to investigate market rates precisely because Mr. Marshall's explanation about the lack of Ohio infrastructure seemed credible and definitive, thereby making any such investigation appear futile.
chunk_0-5: State the specific legal basis for the objection on the record and, if appropriate, instruct my client not to answer.
chunk_0-6: Focus all subsequent questioning on defining the witness's specific, assigned duties and the standard procedures they were trained to follow, in order to establish that discovering the "market price" was outside the scope of their responsibilities.
chunk_0-7: Pivot from my client's current, hearsay-based knowledge and instead focus questioning on the company agent's misrepresentation of the law. I would elicit the specific, step-by-step process Mr. Marshall claimed allowed the company to "take the gas anyway," establishing that he presented a complex legal procedure (unitization) as an automatic and inevitable right to coerce my client into signing the lease.
chunk_0-8: Object on the grounds that the question is incomplete and, to the extent it seeks to elicit conversations with counsel, it is protected by the attorney-client privilege, and instruct the witness not to answer.
chunk_0-9: Instruct the witness to break down the preceding statement counsel is referring to as "that" and explain, in their own words, which specific parts they believe are true and which are not.
chunk_0-10: Object to form, ambiguous as to time. Instruct the witness to answer based only on the information they had at the time of the events, not on what they may have learned in hindsight.
chunk_0-11: Object on the grounds that the question improperly asks the witness to marshal all evidence and exhaust his recollection, and instruct my client to answer only what he can recall at this moment, explicitly stating that discovery is ongoing.
chunk_0-12: Call for a break to confer with my client to confirm their understanding of the question and the full implication of their categorical denial.
chunk_0-13: Interject to object and instruct my client on the record that the attorney-client privilege and work product doctrine protect not just the content of our "conversations," but all aspects of their preparation for this deposition undertaken with my guidance.
chunk_0-14: State the specific legal basis for my objection clearly on the record and instruct counsel to either ask a proper question or certify this one for the judge.
chunk_0-15: Take counsel's offer and ask the deponent directly: "Have your lawyers told you that the statement was false?"
chunk_0-16: On the record, turn to my client and instruct them: "Just listen carefully to the question. If you understand it, please answer it truthfully. If you don't understand it, simply say so, and we will ask counsel to rephrase."
chunk_0-17: Object to the form of the question as argumentative and instruct my witness not to answer. I would then state for the record, "Counsel, you are testifying. If you have a factual question, please ask it, but do not ask my client to agree with your characterizations."
chunk_0-18: Call for a break to instruct my client that their only obligation is to testify truthfully based on their present knowledge, and they are not to volunteer to assist or perform any investigation for opposing counsel.
chunk_0-19: State for the record, "Counsel, I am not testifying. My role is to ensure the witness understands the question. Please ask your next question directly to him so we can proceed."
chunk_0-20: State clearly, "The colloquy between counsel is over. Mr. Kloss, please ask your next question of the witness."
chunk_0-21: Hold on, counsel. I will finish placing my objection on the record, and you will not instruct my witness. Mr. Absalom, do not answer until I have finished and advised you to do so.
chunk_0-22: Focus questioning on the substance and context of Mr. Marshall's answers, specifically exploring how his statement to "expect" activity by a specific date was understood by the deponent and how it influenced the decision to sign the lease, regardless of whether it was a formal "guarantee."
chunk_0-23: Object to the question as compound and instruct my client to answer only the part regarding whether any *other written* guarantees were provided, before addressing any separate questions about oral guarantees.
chunk_0-24: Rephrase the question to focus on the witness's direct knowledge of the system's capabilities or established policy, asking "Are you aware if it was possible for [X to occur]?" or "What was the procedure for [X]?"
chunk_0-25: Re-center the testimony on the fraudulent inducement by asking: "Mr. Absalom, when you read in Exhibit 1 that only two wells were planned for 2008 and had already been drilled elsewhere, what exactly did Mr. Marshall say to you at that time that made you believe there would still be drilling on *your* property, or in your pool, by the end of that year?"
chunk_0-26: On redirect, I will focus entirely on the pre-signing conversations with the landman, Mr. Marshall, to establish the specifics of the fraudulent inducement. My first question will be: "You testified that Mr. Marshall was not honest with you from day one. Tell me, in as much detail as you can remember, everything he told you about Mason Dixon's specific identity as the company that would be drilling on your property and what would happen with your lease."
chunk_0-27: On redirect, I will focus on clarifying the nature of the "change." I will ask the deponent whether counsel *invented* a new position for him, or whether counsel simply reviewed the specific clauses of the pre-existing lease agreement and *explained* the legal meaning of the language he had already signed.
chunk_0-28: Object on the record that this is an improper instruction, not a question, and state, "Counsel, you will not instruct my witness. Ask your next question, and I will handle instructing my client as necessary."
